PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: George Almond
Address: 2491 Nanaimo St, Vancouver B.C.
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? Kirdminster district
Where had you been living before that? Montana
For how many people did you prepare meals? my self & Father
How far was it to your nearest store? about ten miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? about once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, Boer Rolled Oats & dried apples etc

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Not sure
In what quantities did you buy it? One sack at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? about 85¢
How much did you use graham flour? very little
Whole wheat flour? not used
Was flour milled locally? Yes - How far away? 10 miles What year? 1909
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? about 65¢
What other grain products did you use? Corn meal
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina? Other? No other
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? Grain was milled in a clay mill
Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire

No. 1

Pioneer Diet: What did Western Canadian pioneers eat?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to us at the University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: George Almond
Address: 2602 Nanaimo Street, Vancouver, B.C.
Birthplace: England

1. Introductory Questions

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? Kindersley, Saskatchewan
Where had you been living before that? Montana City
For how many people did you prepare meals? Myself & Father
How far was it to your nearest store? A half mile
How often could a visit be made to the store? About once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, Beans, Potatoes, Apples, and Dried Apples

2. Flour and Other Grain Products

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Not sure
In what quantities did you buy it? Usually about a barrel
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.50
How much did you use of each flour?
Whole wheat flour? Not sure
Was flour milled locally? Yes
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.45
What other grain products did you use? Oats, meal
Other? Cornmeal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it? With a hand mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? about 10 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? about 65¢

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Edwardsburg Lactose Syrup

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? about 1 lb.

At what price? about 5 cents each for two.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

...From a cow in the yard or the barnyard...

Butter? ...Yes, from cows...

That was the price of butter? about 20¢

Did you pack eggs for winter? ...Yes...

Did you make butter? ...Yes...

Did you make cheese? ...Yes...

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...usually pork, beef, and mutton...

How did you get fresh meat? ...from local butchers...

How often did you get fresh meat? ...weekly...

How did you preserve meat? ...during the winter months by freezing...

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ...Yes...

If so, what year was it organized? ...1910...

Did you use game? ...Yes...

...mostly pheasant, quail, and turkey...

For how long? ...several years...

What part did fish play in the family diet? ...white fish were available in winter...

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ...mostly fresh...

Kinds? ...for the most part white fish & pickerel...
6. Beverages

What kind of tea did you buy? Kilmuir. At what price? About 35¢.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground. Price? About 35¢. What other beverages were used?

7. Vegetables and Dried Fruits

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? About 35¢. Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1946, Cabbage, Carrots, Onions, Turnips, Beets.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? About 5 lb.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box.

What weight? How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? 2 lb.

What was the price of prunes? Not sure.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

Mostly dried apples, raisins & currents.

8. Preserving

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Not much.

Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons? Other foods?

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning?

That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?

That year did you first preserve meat by canning?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Not much, canning done in the early days.

To what extent? Until the women came later.

Did you make your own vinegar? No.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Food in containers came in about 1913 or 1914.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

In the early days the meals were about the same, with little variation, with the exception of porridge for breakfast, for the most part. Eggs & Bacon, with Beef in the Winter.

Family 1916-7 three members, father 55, two brothers 25 & 15.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ....... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Cannot be sure. It seems a long time ago. However I think there was some kind of pudding & possibly it was Beef & Potatoes etc. Father myself & brother about age 55-25-15 about the year 1907.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, we were fortunate.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

In the early days the meals were about the same, with little variation, except for the addition of porridge for breakfast, for the most part. Eggs & Bacon, with Beef in the Winter.

January 1916-7 three members, Father 5'3", two brothers 2'3" + 1'5"

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ..........

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Cannot be sure, it seems a long time ago. However, I think there was some kind of pudding & possibly pie with Beef & Potatoes etc.

Father myself & brother about age 5'3" - 2'3" - 1'5" about the year 1907.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, we were fortunate.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the early days everything had to be prepared the hard way, for example if you cooked a chicken, one would have to remove the feathers first, more work. At the present one can cook things that are fairly purchased etc.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I would say conditions seem to improve on the farm generally a short time before & after the first world war, farm commodities had begun to improve in price, which had the effect of making conditions better for the most part.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Most settlers in the early days seemed to depend on the mail orders houses for their supplies etc., money being for the most part very scarce and difficult to obtain; a promising grain crop would often be frozen, which would create unusual difficulties. If a good crop was obtained, it was often advisable to store grain on the farm until prices improved.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In the early days, every dish had to be prepared the hard way. For example, if you wanted a chicken, you would have to purchase the feathers first, then cook them.

But the farmers on our own farms didn't have to worry about this. They would say, "Well, we'll just go to the store and buy some."

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and homemade?

Before the First World War, farm animals had to be fed hay grown on the farm itself. After the war, the emphasis shifted to purchasing food from stores.

The effect of making conditions better for the next generation.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and preparing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include stories not mentioned above, quality, methods of marketing, prices, problems of storage, shortages, and other details.

Must details in the early days:

- Meals had to be prepared by hand.
- There was very scarce and difficult to obtain flour, sugar, and other staples.
- The most hardworking families would often be the poorest, while those who could afford more would be poorer.

If you could afford to buy goods on the farm market, it was often preferable.
